title: How to Graph Sine and Cosine Functions

steps.title: Draw a coordinate plane.
steps.content: Draw a coordinate plane. For a sine or cosine graph, simply go from 0 to 2π on the x-axis, and -1 to 1 on the y-axis, intersecting at the origin (0, 0). Both y = sin ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y = cos ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle y=\cos(x)} repeat the same shape from negative infinity to positive infinity on the x-axis (you'll generally only graph a portion of it). Use the basic equations as given: y = sin ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y = c o s ( x ) {\displaystyle y=cos(x)}

steps.title: Graph the basic form of y = sin ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} .
steps.content: Graph the basic form of y = sin ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} . Plot and connect the points (0, 0), (π/2, 1), (π, 0), and (3π/2, -1) with a continuous curve. Both y = sin ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y = cos ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle y=\cos(x)} never go past -1 or 1 on the y-axis. Since you are only hand-drawing your graphs , there is no precise scale, but it must be accurate at certain points.

steps.title: Graph the basic form of y = c o s ( x ) {\displaystyle y=cos(x)} .
steps.content: Graph the basic form of y = c o s ( x ) {\displaystyle y=cos(x)} . Plot and connect the points (0, 1), (π/2, 0), (π, -1), and (3π/2, 0) with a continuous curve. It may be helpful to use two separate colors to distinguish between sine and cosine.

steps.title: Use the standard equation to define your variables.
steps.content: Use the standard equation to define your variables. y = A sin ⁡ ( B x + C ) + D {\displaystyle y=A\sin(Bx+C)+D} Find your values of A, B, C, and D. Note that in the basic equation for sine, A = 1, B = 1, C = 0, and D = 0.

steps.title: Calculate the period.
steps.content: Calculate the period. Divide your period on the x-axis into four sections that are equal distances apart, just like in the basic equations. The y-values will still alternate from 0, 1, 0, and -1 just like in the basic equation. Period = 2 π B {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}={\frac {2\pi }{B}}}

steps.title: Calculate the amplitude.
steps.content: Calculate the amplitude. Amplitude = A {\displaystyle {\text{Amplitude}}=A} Multiply the y-values you have by A, and graph these new points. If A is negative, the graph will flip over the x-axis. This is called a reflection.

steps.title: Calculate the phase shift.
steps.content: Calculate the phase shift. Phase shift = C B {\displaystyle {\text{Phase shift}}={\frac {C}{B}}} This will move the graph to the left or right. For each x-value in the period, move the x-value to the left by C/B if C/B is negative, or move each x-value to the right by C/B if C/B is positive.

steps.title: Calculate the vertical shift.
steps.content: Calculate the vertical shift. Vertical shift = D {\displaystyle {\text{Vertical shift}}=D} For each y-value, move the y-value up by D if D is positive, or move the y-value down if D is negative.

steps.title: Graph the final function.
steps.content: Graph the final function. After each transformation has been applied, your graph is finished!
